verses.text: Come, let us sing to the LORD; let us make a joyful noise to the Rock of our salvation.
verses.comment: ‘Rock’ here alludes to God’s steadfastness, a theme later applied to Christ as the cornerstone (see 1 Cor. 10:4).

verses.text: Let us come before his presence with thanksgiving; let us make a joyful noise to him with songs of praise.
verses.comment: Both public and liturgical worship are in view; many early Christians interpreted this as referring to the Eucharistic thanksgiving.

verses.text: For the LORD is a great God, and a great King above all gods.
verses.comment: The psalmist affirms God’s universal kingship, foreshadowing Christ as King of Kings (Rev. 19:16).

verses.text: In his hand are the depths of the earth; the heights of the mountains are his also.
verses.comment: ‘Hand’ represents authority. The Catholic tradition sees divine sovereignty in all creation, something reflected in the Church’s sacramental worldview.

verses.text: The sea is his, for he made it, and his hands formed the dry land.
verses.comment: Creation themes here recall Genesis 1. The language of ‘hands’ again points to personal care, echoing the Catholic understanding of God’s providence.

verses.text: Come, let us worship and bow down; let us kneel before the LORD, our Maker.
verses.comment: A call to physical worship: bowing and kneeling are actions central to both Jewish and Christian liturgical worship; the Catholic liturgy maintains these postures today.

verses.text: For he is our God, and we are the people of his pasture, and the sheep of his hand. Today, if you hear his voice,
verses.comment: The shepherd imagery is later fulfilled in Jesus (John 10:11). The ‘Today’ signals ongoing call to obedience, much emphasized in the Catholic understanding of continuing salvation.

verses.text: do not harden your hearts, as at Meribah, as on the day at Massah in the wilderness,
verses.comment: The wilderness rebellion is a warning. Catholics read this as teaching the necessity of perseverance, cooperating with God’s grace over a lifetime.

verses.text: When your fathers tested me, they tried me, though they had seen my work.
verses.comment: Even after witnessing miracles, the Israelites doubted. This highlights the dangers of presuming upon God’s grace—an idea key to Catholic soteriology.

verses.text: For forty years I was grieved with that generation and said, 'They are a people who go astray in their hearts, and they have not known my ways.'
verses.comment: The grumbling generation was excluded from rest. Within Catholic teaching, this prefigures purgation and the journey toward the Promised Land as heaven.

verses.text: So I swore in my wrath, 'They shall not enter my rest.'
verses.comment: ‘Rest’ here points both to the land and—by extension—spiritual rest in Christ (Heb. 4). Catholics have traditionally linked this to the fullness of salvation and the reality of rest in God.
